page.title: 10Shepshed's Local Language
page.content: Before the age of modern transport {Shepshed}was quite an insular village with a good deal of intermarriage. This meant that a{local language developed of which several phrases have continued to survive. Men greeting other men of whom they have only a casual acquaintance use the term{"hey up surrey". Around the village are a number of footpaths between houses. These are known as{"jitties" or"snickets".}While anyone walking on the pavement would be walking on the{ "pad" or "coursey". A child who was cheeky would be {"chelpin"}and might be admonished with{"less of your chelp". A sign of bad weather to come would be announced by the comment{"it looks {black over Bill's mother's".
